Jason Peplinski
May 20, 2019 at 4:18 PM ·

I’m back!! Today I am advocating with my tri-county colleagues for students.

I have some big news for Simi Valley residents. Last week I was in San Francisco with my colleague, Ron Todo, to lobby a credit rating agency to give our district an upgrade in credit rating. We found out today that our efforts were successful. SVUSD has received its 3rd upgrade in 5 years. Over the life of our bond, these efforts will have saved or avoided over 20 million in tax liability to the residents of Simi Valley. This is evidence that our fiscal position is much improved and that we are working hard to protect the tax payers in Simi Valley who have been so generous in their support of school bond measures. Kudos to our staff and School Board for their hard work over the years to earn these upgrades. Super proud today!

post_text: THE SVUSD BOARD OF TRUSTEES HAS APPROVED PAY RAISES FOR ALL EMPLOYEES (CERTIFICATED, CLASSIFIED AND MANAGEMENT) OF 2.75%, RETROACTIVE TO JULY 1, 2018. Some additional changes to medical benefits, professional development opportunities and class sizes were also approved in the new contracts. Elementary class size ratios of students to teachers for grades JK/TK to 3rd will be an average of 24-1. TITLE 1 elementary class size ratios of students to teacher for grades 4th to 6th will be an average of 29-1 (this affects Arroyo, Berylwood, Park View and Santa Susana elementary schools).

post_text: EVERY 15 MINUTES: At today's assembly, Royal High School's juniors and seniors filled the gym to watch the student-produced movie from the previous day's events, including the car crash, jail booking, emergency room, mortuary and other scenes. Then they listened to their classmates who were directly involved in the program read their "final" letters to family and friends. The program was wrapped up by speaker Matt Dies, whose daughter, Mallory, was killed after being hit by a car driven by a drunk driver while walking in Santa Barbara on 2013. Mallory would be 33 this week and Mr. Dies spoke simply and poignantly about his daughter. He urged the students to not drink and drive, and instead to call their parents for a ride.

post_text: EVERY 15 MINUTES someone in the United States loses their life in a drunk driving related accident. Today, the juniors and seniors at Royal High School will experience a realistic staging of a fatal drunk driving accident involving their classmates. This morning’s Every 15 Minutes event started with the announcement of a different student’s “death” every 15 minutes and the reading of that student’s obituary. As each is read over the school’s PA system by Principal Keith Derrick, a police officer, counselor and the Grim Reaper enter that student’s class (they are not there) and announce his/her death in person. Then the Grim Reaper places a red rose at that student’s desk. No one talks. The classroom is somber and serious as this happens.

post_text: IMPORTANT INFORMATION: Every year, Royal High School and Simi Valley High School alternate the production of Every 15 Minutes. This long-standing drunk-driving awareness program is aimed at our high school juniors and seniors and is hosted by our PTAs and many community organizations. This year, Every 15 Minutes will be held at Royal High School. It will begin tomorrow (Wednesday, March 20) with a realistic recreated "crash" scene, complete with police, fire and other emergency personnel, who attend the "crash" and work it as if it's real. The "crash" scene will be set up in Royal's west parking lot and neighbors have been notified. Please do not worry if you see police activity around Royal tomorrow morning. Thank you. (The photo is from last year's Every 15 Minutes at Simi Valley High School. The roses signify people who were "killed" in a drunk-driving related accident. It's estimated that every 15 minutes in the United States, someone is killed in a drunk-driving related accident.)

post_text: Dr. Victor DeNoble, a research scientist formerly working with Philip Morris on tobacco research beginning in the 1980s, visited our middle and high schools this week to talk about his work researching the serious dangers of tobacco use, vaping and e-cigarettes. A whistleblower against the tobacco industry, Dr. DeNoble's efforts and Congressional testimonies helped introduce stricter control laws around tobacco products. Here he is on Friday speaking to students at Simi Valley High School. For more information about his work, his website is http://www.victordenoble.com.
